texts.definition: Game elements that diegetically represent players, providing their main means of interacting with the world and whose fate is connected to the players' success and failure in the game.
markups: <style="Definition">Game elements that diegetically represent players, providing their main means of interacting with the world and whose fate is connected to the players' success and failure in the game.</style>

Many games let players be represented in them by one of the agents in the game, often as a human or an anthropomorphic persona (but in some cases less human-like entities as vehicles, blobs, etc.). Echoing the idea from religion that some gods can incarnate into beings on Earth to be able to interact there, these forms are called Avatars. The presence of Avatars when their players are not interacting with the game system is in this case not consistent with the original meaning; games having this design are in fact closer to using the Horse concept in Voodoo.

The use of <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> can be for several reasons: to let players take a specific role in the events that unfold during gameplay, limit their perception of the game world, localize the area where they can affect the game world, or create game elements the player must keep safe. Through doing this, the players' attention can be focused on specific parts of the game and provide an anchor for the players' emotional investment in the games.

Note: When abstract and representational forms of of diegetic persons exist, both forms are commonly referred to as Characters. That the term Avatars is not used in this case is in compliance with the original meaning of the term since it implies a clear distinction between the two, and this is not the case in those situations. However, this pattern is described to be useful regardless if an abstract representation exists as well.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Avatars can be found in most games having a game world since players needs some focal point within the world to affect it. The pattern was already present in early arcade and video games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Wars">Space Wars</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style> series, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bomberman%20series">Bomberman series</link></style> make use of this pattern, and this tradition is continued in many modern games following the aesthetics from those games (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Continuity">Continuity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Icy%20Tower">Icy Tower</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zombiepox">Zombiepox</link></style>). The case could even be made that it is present in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> even if players can move other pieces, since losing one's king is equal to losing the game. Likewise, one could argue that in most traditional, sports such as Wrestling and Soccer, the players themselves are <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style>, noting that their actions are restricted and that it shouldn't matter for the games' definitions who participate as long as they match certain criteria.

Although not strictly necessary in single-player FPS games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> since the players don't need to be able to see themselves (other than in mirrors for believability issues), <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> are needed in the multiplayer modes of these games and FPS games specifically designed for team-based gameplay such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>. Likewise, players are represented as <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> in Massively Multiplayer Online Roleplaying Games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>, but here players often have a greater possibility to personalize their appearance through physical characteristics and equipment. Games using third person perspectives, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed">Assassin's Creed</link></style> series and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lego%20Star%20Wars%20series">Lego Star Wars series</link></style>, let players see their own <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> in relation to the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>, making it easier to understand scales and simulate an awareness of one's surroundings not purely based on what is in line of sight. The use of vehicles, e.g. cars in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Need%20for%20Speed%20Series">Need for Speed Series</link></style> and anti-aircraft artillery pieces <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20War%20II%20Online">World War II Online</link></style>, or blobs, as in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gish">Gish</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mercury%20Meltdown">Mercury Meltdown</link></style>, show that not only anthropomorphic representations can be used as <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style>.

The computer game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paradroid">Paradroid</link></style> used an extended variant of the <style="CurrentLink">Avatar</style> pattern. The player controlled a defenseless robot, which could control one other robot, and the gameplay consisted of switching between these second-order <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> to defeat all robots on a spaceship.

The creatures in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Black%20&%20White%20series">Black & White series</link></style> are not <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> since they are only indirectly controlled by players and they affect the game world through an intangible hand.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

While the <style="CurrentLink">Avatar</style> presents players with a tangible presence in a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> is the abstract representation containing game information about aspects such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>. However, since these in many cases affect each other it is often necessary to consider these two patterns together.

Two main requirements are needed for players to perceive themselves as having Avatars in the game. First, that a single entity in the Game World is their primary ability to affect the game, i.e. that person is their Focus Loci (since controlling several game elements give rise to the Units patterns). Second, that the game (or other players) can affect the players' success or failure regarding gameplay through the entity. This does not mean that players only can have one specific Avatar during a complete game session, simply that one only has one at any given time. Examples of using more than one Avatar include Fahrenheit, where the player switching between several different protagonists in the game story, and Cursor*10 where players cooperate with previous instances of their Avatars. Games such as Sleepwalker and Mario & Luigi: Partners in Time blur the distinction between Avatars and Units by having several diegetic persons that they have to take care of (they can be said to instantiate a weak form of Parallel Lives but where the Avatars are controlled as one group and losing one may immediately have bad effects). A weaker form of this blurring can be found in games where players' have Companions more limited than full-fledged AI Players that accompany the Avatars, e.g. the dogs in the Fallout series, Shadow Dancer, and Fable II, and the various Companions in Torchlight. Another variation of Avatars is to use them in a layered fashion where a player's Avatar controls another game element directly. This typically presented to the player by replacing the Avatar with the other game element and providing the actions of the game element to the player. Examples of this are the possessing of other droids in Paradroid and the possibility to enter the driving position in vehicles in Battlefield 1942. Note that the controlling of Avatars can be dislocated from the Avatars themselves by using God Fingers to give the actual instructions on what they should do - the Sims series is an example of this. This is not Indirect Control of the Avatars since players do not have to act through any other game element to reach the effects they want, it is simply that the giving of instructions are done indirectly.

Choosing which Abilities the Avatars should provide naturally depends on the intended gameplay and theme, but some are more likely than others. Movement is very common ability used with Avatars, both to allow explorations and re-positioning in the Game Worlds and since players are used to thinking about themselves in relation to their locomotion. Related to Movement is the consideration if the Avatars should be Diegetically Tangible Game Items - if they are they can become Obstacles to the Movement of other game elements, and in Multiplayer Games, other Avatars. Also related to this is if they should extend Zones of Control, i.e. affect the Abilities of those next to them. Another common ability is perception, i.e. that the Avatars can detect some aspects of the Game World but not other. Note that this can be used both to limit what actions are possible (e.g. only being able to shoot enemies which are in the Avatar's Line of Sight) but also to limit the players' information about the game state, i.e. provide a form of Fog of War and make God Views impossible. That latter is typically a natural consequence of First-Person Views unless the Game World has very few Obstacles. Combat is also a common ability for Avatars and makes Capture and Eliminate goals possible. Although more common for Characters, actions related to Transferable Items, e.g. Trading and Stealing, can sometimes be appropriate for Avatars. A rather rare ability for Avatars but which can be vital in Multiplayer first-person shooters is to allow some Avatars to have the Privileged Ability of being able to act as a Spawn Point. Besides what actions the avatars can perform, their likelihood to succeed can be linked either to the Character statistics, player skill, or Player/Character Skill Composites and the choices made here typically determine the proportions importance of Dexterity-Based Actions and Tactical Planning in the game.

Many games start with a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> available through the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> and then expanding this through <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> as gameplay progresses. By doing this, as is done for example in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario">Super Mario series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda%20series">The Legend of Zelda series</link></style>, the game can provide a <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> in the beginning and a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> as the game commences. Note that <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> can be given either to <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>; the abilities are linked to <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> when the abilities are only observable through actions in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> or there are no observable abstract representations of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> behind the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style>. These <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> provide ways of having <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> even in games that do not have explicit <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. Another option to providing <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> to <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> is through diegetically facilitated them through <style="Link"><link="location-fixed-abilities">Location-Fixed Abilities</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> can provide both <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> while <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style> can protected against <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>. Further, the game design can support the <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> by limiting access to game areas until various <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> to gain entry to <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, have been acquired.

Linking the success or failure of the gameplay to <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> can be done in many ways. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race">Race</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Connection">Connection</link></style> goals naturally depend on the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> movement if their positions are used to determine if the end conditions have been reached. <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> can likewise be used if the game uses the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style>' modes of perception to judge what has been found. The use of <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> (and by extension <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style>) due to <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> is a very common way to make <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> vulnerable and players' succeed linked to them, but <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> (including <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>), or losses of <style="Link"><link="scores">Score</link></style> points or <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> are other possibilities.  Although these introduce negative possibilities for the players, once these vulnerabilities have been established they allow for the goals of <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style> to be linked to the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style>. In general, any type of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> that can be avoided through <style="CurrentLink">Avatar</style> <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> leads to players having <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals. More specific goals that can be introduced in this way, especially when combined with <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> and common <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals are <style="Link"><link="king-hill">King of the Hill</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="last-man-standing">Last Man Standing</link></style>. The death or <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Elimination</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> typically either signifies the end of the game (if <style="Link"><link="permadeath">Permadeath</link></style> is used), <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> before the next round begins or other types of <style="Link"><link="death-consequences">Death Consequences</link></style>, or the loss of one of the <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> available (and in the last case requires <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style> or the activation of a new <style="CurrentLink">Avatar</style>). This makes the <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style> goal an integral part of many games using <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style>.

Besides these two necessary conditions, the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> relation to its surroundings and other diegetic persons are fundamental in how they are perceived. The use of <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style> not only help define the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> but also the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> through how they affect them. <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style> can serve many of these purposes while also having the functionality of various types of <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>. That game elements in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> can help define <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> becomes especially true if there are many types of playable <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> or the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> are affected differently than <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> and other <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>, e.g. through having different rules concerning <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style>. Reversely, if <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> block <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style> or not when this pattern is used affects the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> relation to the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Automated%20Responses">Automated Responses</link></style>, actions initiated by the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> themselves without player interference, are ways to inform players about possible actions (e.g. by the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> glancing at them or commenting them) or possible dangers (e.g. how <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%202">Assassin's Creed 2</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Prince%20of%20Persia">Prince of Persia</link></style> make animations of regaining their balance after nearly falling of ledges when players have moved them to close).

Additional design possibilities exist to let players have closer attachment with their <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style>, with two common approaches being related to what ability or appearance they have. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Initial%20Personalization">Initial Personalization</link></style> let players choose or modify the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> before gameplay starts so they can suit the players' preferences regarding either gameplay or theme. <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>, which can either be a continuation of the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Initial%20Personalization">Initial Personalization</link></style> or an independent feature, let players fine-tune their <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> as gameplay progresses. The effort these two patterns require from players is in itself a potential cause for them to feel an attachment to them; the <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> makes it more compelling to care about the outcome. Although most often related to <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> and diegetic-related patterns such as <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style> can be applied when <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> exist.

While the pattern <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> handles abstract <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style> of diegetic individuals, it may be pointless to argue that both patterns exist in a game if there only exists a few <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style> and these are constantly presented to players. A typical example of this can be found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%201942">Battlefield 1942</link></style> or the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> where <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interfaces</link></style> display <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> values, <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style> left, and active <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapon</link></style>; here it is easier to consider these patterns (especially <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> as being linked to <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> rather than <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="equipment-slots">Equipment Slots</link></style> can allow limited handling of <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> without having to commit to the use of complete <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventory</link></style> systems. In contrast, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%202">Battlefield 2</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%202">Team Fortress 2</link></style> store additional information related to <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> and gameplay performances which qualify them to make use of the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> pattern. Likewise, <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> (including <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style>) that do not develop over gameplay (due to being either permanent or very temporary) can be viewed as belong to <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> unless the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> pattern is used for additional purposes in games.

<style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> can actually be used in game sessions where their players are not present or providing input. <style="Link"><link="mules">Mules</link></style> are <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> that ensure that <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> continue taking actions while players are away from the game for extended periods of time. <style="Link"><link="ghosts">Ghosts</link></style> are the use of <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> to provide players of racing games with representations of how previous players (including themselves) gamed. An example of this is the platform game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Icy%20Tower">Icy Tower</link></style>, which makes use of <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> as markers for the highest floor reached by other players, making them part of a <style="Link"><link="high-score-lists">High Score List</link></style> presented inside the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> can take over avatars to provide some actions to make the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> diegetic wait while the players is not providing input, but can also be used to support <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> gameplay or <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> is a diegetic pattern which is impossible to use without some form of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. Given their importance in the overall gameplay, they do tend to have <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> if they have any <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Movement</link></style>. Although <style="Link"><link="third-person-views">Third-Person Views</link></style> (or reflections) are necessary for players to be able to perceive their own <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, and may be necessary to support <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style>, they easily break <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> since players may have perceive their <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> than the game presents them. Games with purely <style="Link"><link="first-person-views">First-Person Views</link></style> can have implied <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style>, often encouraged through showing what <style="Link"><link="tools">Tool</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapon</link></style> is active as if held by the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style>, and are easily induced in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> since players can see the other players' <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style>. Depending on the diegetic theme, some abilities might be more or less believable as belonging to the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> (e.g. being able to kill enemies at a distance in a realistic game without any type of ranged <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>) and having these may weaken the presence of the pattern.

The difference or similarity of both appearance and abilities between players' <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> and <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> can be used to magnify the diegetic difference in power. This is often done for <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> (e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/God%20of%20War%20series">God of War series</link></style>) but is some cases for all <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> (e.g. in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Shadow%20of%20the%20Colossus">Shadow of the Colossus</link></style>). By having a large difference in size and at the same time restricting the movement of the opponent, the game can provide <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> but not overwhelmingly so even the depiction claims this.

When <style="CurrentLink">Avatars'</style> fate are linked to how well players complete the gameplay, this can provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> but this can also be done through supporting players in having sympathies towards the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style>. This can be achieved diegetically through a design so that the <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> have a appealing personality or appearance, have been mistreated, or have abilities players would like to have. However, <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> do not usually have strongly developed personalities as this can prevent the players from interpreting what they want into the <style="CurrentLink">Avatar's</style> actions. Further, if the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Avatar">Avatar</link></style> can initiate actions on its own, e.g. in the form of <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>, this can lessens the players' <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> and may destroy an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illusion%20of%20Influence">Illusion of Influence</link></style> as well as their <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> directed towards other objects or players in the Game World.

Avatar Personalization is the ability to change Avatars' appearance, which although it does not direct affect gameplay can be important. While Avatars names are not part of their diegetic appearance, Naming can be seen as a variant of this personalization since it changes how the Avatars are presented to players. In games such as Tiger Woods PGA Tour and the third installment of the Fallout series, the Initial Personalization not only includes gameplay options but also purely cosmetic choices. By doing so, players have two different avenues to create Emotional Engrossment to the Avatars and the game in general already before gameplay begins. For Multiplayer Games, Handles presented Geospatial Game Widgets hovering above the Avatars can make each players' identity unique. Going further, differences in Avatars' appearances or Game State Indicators can be vital to express Asymmetric Abilities and Privileged Abilities in order to support players, both in finding Achilles' Heels in enemies and supporting team play, and Team Combos in particular, within Teams of Avatars. For games with Functional Roles these differences can easily be shown as changes in general appearance or clothing, while games with Vehicles or Equipment such as Armor, Cosmetic Game Items, Tools, and Weapons can simply integrate the presentation of these with the Avatars. In other cases, e.g. games with Power-Ups, Geospatial Game Widgets may be more appropriate instead, as for example is done for the showing that someone has the Quad Damage Power-Up in the Quake series.

In games with <style="Link"><link="hybrid-gameplay-spaces">Hybrid Gameplay Spaces</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-avatar-proximity">Player-Avatar Proximity</link></style> modify <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> so they can not only interact with other <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> (and other virtual gameplay elements) but also with players.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

Given that Avatars represent player agency in games and are inserted in the game when players enter games, they are examples of Game Element Insertion (having them present without players or their proxies controlling is possible but these version of Avatars should more correctly be called Horses). Avatars are one way of giving players' Focus Loci that maintains Diegetic Consistency since they are diegetic entities, and as such they typically provide Freedom of Choice and Illusion of Influence from specific points within Game Worlds. Since they are also tightly connected to the players' success or failure in the game, they are a natural point of Emotional Engrossment. When they are the diegetic representations of players' Characters, they also are an expression of player Ownership. Depending on the level of personality and goals described through the Characters, and how acceptable those goals are to the players, Avatars also encourage Roleplaying, but since the appearance of an Avatar and its' possible actions restrict what players can do, the more these things are explicitly defined the more they restrict what type of Roleplaying is diegetically consistent. Even if the game does not present goals Roleplaying can emerge if players choose their own Player Defined Goals.

Representing the main protagonists in many cases, <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> are often vital for <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> although they are also bounded by the specifics of the theme. Letting players engage in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Naming">Naming</link></style> their <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> risks breaking this consistency but does provide a minimal level of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Avatar%20Personalization">Avatar Personalization</link></style>.

As long as players are trying to achieve some form of goal while playing, <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> are human-controlled <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>. When encountered in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> where players have goals to <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> each other, they are also <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>. As <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> are located within <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Spatial%20Engrossment">Spatial Engrossment</link></style> is a common effect of having the pattern. Games have <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structures</link></style> when players' perception of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> is limited to one <style="CurrentLink">Avatar</style> and only what that <style="CurrentLink">Avatar</style> can perceive.

Games with <style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> can provide a <style="Link"><link="possibility-anonymity">Possibility of Anonymity</link></style> through having only allowing <style="Link"><link="mediated-gameplay">Mediated Gameplay</link></style> through them or other restricted <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Avatars</style> that have <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> give rise to goals concerning to <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> these or <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> attempts to exploit them.
